title: Energy conservation - 4 mg sphere with 3 nC charge

content.description: A small sphere of mass <math alttext="4.0 times 10 raised to the negative 6 power, kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>4.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mstyle></math> and net charge <math alttext="positive 3.0 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mpadded> <mo>+</mo> <mn>3.0</mn> </mpadded> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>nC</mtext> </mstyle> </math> is moving along a straight line that is equidistant from two larger fixed spheres, as shown in the figure. Each fixed sphere has a net charge of <math alttext="positive 6.0 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>6.0</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mstyle></math>. The moving sphere first passes through Point <math alttext="O" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, which is <math alttext="0.30 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>0.30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> from each fixed sphere, and later Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, which is <math alttext="0.20 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math> from each fixed sphere.
